channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Get your foot in the door! UK Remote Jr. Perl Developer
item.description: Our client is currently looking to staff up some Jr. Perl developers for a 100% remote (within the UK), permanent position. They want to find some fresh talent that can adapt and flourish in this role. Having modern Perl foundations and understandings is important, but the client is willing to overlook some knowledge gaps for the right developer who is eager to learn.

item.title: Cruise into this Dreamy Career. Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an international company who pride themselves on making online trading a breeze. After twenty-plus years cruising the financial waters, they’re subject matter experts who provide a stable, engaging environment for their crew. Located in glorious Malta, they offer a supportive team that believes in open communication and solving problems together.

item.title: Can’t find the right job? Build your own! Remote Perl role in Australia
item.description: If you’re a senior Perl developer — you’ve already got the most important component of what our client is looking for. The other important bits: in an ideal world, you’ll have experience with most or all of Catalyst, REST, Dancer2, Moo, DBlx::Class, MySQL, Postgres, and docker. Want to add extra flair? AngularJS or Vue would take you to the next level.

item.title: Make a Difference AND a Paycheque. 100% remote (within the UK) Mid-level Perl developer role
item.description: The best things in life may be free, but you’ll get paid for making them accessible when you join our client’s team. Their mission is simple: empower citizens to participate in civic matters. How do they do it? By providing all the technology, tools, and data that people need at no charge.

item.title: Did You Get the Job You Wanted for Christmas? US-based remote Perl role
item.description: Now that the blitz of wrapping paper and ribbon has subsided, it’s time to take stock. Did you get everything you wanted? What about a new job where your skills and know-how as a Senior Perl Developer can make a real impact? If that was missing from your stocking this year, we have one last gift for you.

item.title: Learn Yiddish on YiddishPOP
item.description: When my kids were small we subscribed to (the Hebrew edition of) BrainPOP and we all loved it. As I can see they have English, Spanish and French editions. They also created this series of introduction to Yiddish. It is cute.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 145
item.description: Simon's use of a sliding window method to solve the Palindromic Tree task is really cool. Keep it up great work.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 145: Tree Product
item.description: Roger discusses his Lua solution to the Palindromic Tree task. His Rust solution to the Dot Product task is also cool. Thank you for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: How to find palindromes quickly
item.description: Cool use of regex to find Palindromes. Thanks for sharing your knowledge with us.

item.title: Dot Product
item.description: Mark once again shared solutions in Raku and Wolfram. I am very impressed with his Wolfram solution. You don't want to miss it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 145
item.description: Luis sharing the power of PDL with a one-liner. You don't want to miss it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 145: the last challenge of the year!
item.description: Luca's one-liner in Raku is always the main attraction and not to be missed. Please do check it out yourself.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 145: Palindromes
item.description: An exclusive blog post for each task gives more space for discussion. Simply loved reading the story. Thank you.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 145: Dot Product
item.description: Laurent shared more than just Perl and Raku solutions this week. Plenty of guest language to keep you busy. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #145
item.description: James's solution is always magical and compact. And on top of that you get a detailed description. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: PWC145 - Palindromic Tree
item.description: I am glad Flavio didn't have any questions about the Palindromic Tree task. Also we got real graphs using Raku. Thanks for sharing with us.

item.title: PWC145 - Dot Product
item.description: Flavio gave us a flavour of Raku classes in this blog post. You should check it out if you want to know more.

item.title: Products above Trees?: The Weekly Challenge #145
item.description: Another one-liner for the Dot Product task and a very clever one by Dave. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Palin' Dot with Raku and Perl
item.description: I really enjoyed the Perl solution by Arne as you can see the Raku flavour in it. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 145: Palindromic Tree
item.description: Too much to handle in one liner. These solutions need to be kept safe for the next generation. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 145: Dot Product
item.description: Cool use of the CPAN module Math::Matrix results in a classic solution. Thank you Abigail.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 141
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 145
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Dot Product" and "Palindromic Tree" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 146
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "10001st Prime Number" and "Curious Fraction Tree". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: List of new CPAN distributions - Dec 2021
Gabor self reporting for 2022.01.01
item.description: Covering November-December of 2021 and the plans for 2022

item.title: Happy 2022! And a reflection
item.description: Why and how can Flavio write so many blog posts? How could you also do it?

item.title: 20 best Perl questions at StackOverflow in 2021
10 best perl distributions created in 2021 (metacpan rating)
Do-It-Yourself Lexical Pragmas
item.description: This blog post is about writing Perl code whose configuration changes are limited to a lexical scope, just like built-in pragmata such as strict or warnings.

item.title: Advent of Code Days 15 to 24, with some gaps
Draft: Dancer2 Deprecation Policy
item.description: See the open issue.

item.title: My new modules in 2021
item.description: The Perl modules Leon created in 2021: Crypt::Passphrase - Thread::Csp - autocroak; in Raku: Crypt::Passphrase - Net::MQTT

item.title: AoC 2021/18 - Fishy accordion
item.description: Something about balancing binary trees.

item.title: Avoid Yoda conditions in Perl you should
item.description: Just use warnings and strictures, he says.

item.title: AoC 2021/17 - Ballistic
item.description: This day's puzzle is about throwing stuff around. It involves some physics models.

item.title: Capture STDOUT and STDERR of external program using Capture::Tiny
#545 - Happy, Healthy, and Prosperous New Year!
item.description:
Hi everyone!

Let me start by welcoming you to the new year! Let me also use the opportunity to thank Mohammad S. Anwar for his dedication in both editing every other edition of the Perl Weekly Newsletter and his very own Weekly Challenge. Let me also thank Dave Cross for his immense help making our grammar a bit more bearable and the various Open Source projects he creates. (e.g. the CPAN Dashboard or The Perl Planetarium). If you also like their work please thank them in an email, a blog post, or by supporting them via Patreon for Mohammad or via GitHub for Dave. They won't become wealthy from this, but receiving a paycheck every month from tens of supporters give a huge boost to the ego and makes one create even more for the public.

As for me, you might recall I've been learning Spanish for more than 3 years and started to learn Ladino (aka. Judeo-Spanish) a few weeks ago. Learning a foreign language is a totally different experience than learning a programming language. If for nothing else, because you don't get immediate feedback to your mistakes from a compiler. Well. Except if you use an application that helps you. My open source mindset quickly kicked in. I found an Open Source platform called LibreLingo that will help you learn languages. It is still in very early version, but started to use that platform to be able to practice Ladino and also started to contribute to the project. I'll share more about it when enough progress was made to show something in public. Until then you are invited to check it out.

Enjoy the year ahead!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
